Award.AwardTitle: Influence of Titanium on Water Incorporation, Rheology and Seismic Properties of Olivine
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Earth's interior may contain as much water as in the oceans, but it occurs in trace amounts in silicate minerals which make up the Earth's mantle. In the upper mantle, olivine is the major phase, occupying at least 60% of its volume. It dominates the physical properties such as the viscosity involved in convection and plate tectonics. Deformation experiments show that water has a large effect on the viscosity of olivine, lowering it by an order of magnitude or more. How much water is contained in olivine depends on the capacity of the crystal structure to incorporate it as a trace element, but also on the availability of water. Except above subducting plates, the capacity of olivine to incorporate water substantially exceeds the water available in the mantle, so that the olivine is far from water saturation. By contrast, published deformation experiments have only been carried out either dry or under water-saturated conditions. The proposed experiments will be conducted under water-undersaturated conditions representative of those in the Earth.

The bonding environment of hydrogen in the crystal lattice of olivine can be investigated with infrared spectroscopy. Comparison of spectra from water-undersaturated xenoliths with those from water saturated experiments show significant differences. The xenolith spectra can be reproduced when trace amounts of titanium are added to synthetic olivine encapsulated in noble metals like platinum. The spectra confirm that the amount and bonding environment of hydrogen in these synthetic samples matches the natural samples. Exploratory deformation experiments show that these samples are weaker than dry samples, suggesting that water saturation is not necessary for water-weakening. If confirmed these findings imply that in the presence of titanium hydrogen is comparatively stable in the olivine structure, and that even small amounts of water will induce weakening. This has implications not only for the rheology of the Earth, but potentially also for drier planetary bodies such as the Moon or Mars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A still unresolved question is why plate tectonics operates on Earth, but not on Venus or Mars. The Earth's volatile budget may be part of the answer, but to confirm this we need to understand how volatiles affect the properties of rocks in the interior of the Earth. This study investigated the deformation behavior of polycrystalline olivine (peridot), the major mineral in Earth's upper mantle. The experiments were conducted with a range of volatile contents, in particular water (hydrogen). This necessitated finding ways to retain hydrogen in the experimental apparatus at high temperatures and pressures for the required experimental duration. Water retention was achieved by encapsulating the samples in platinum.

A key component of the project was to quantify the water content in the rocks by infrared spectroscopy. This technique allows fingerprinting the defect site where hydrogen is incorporated in the olivine crystal structure. Contrary to the expectations from existing defect models, the defect that results in water weakening of olivine consists of hydrogen together with a tretravalent trace element in olivine, titanium. The results of the deformation experiments show a linear relationship between water content and strength of olivineaggregates. One implication is that the deeper portions of continental cratons, which are observed to contain significant amounts of water, can't be too warm, as they would be too weak to persist for billions of years in a convecting upper mantle.

A second part of the project was the measurement of seismic properties of polycrystalline olivine. Seismic imaging is the predominant method of gaining knowledge about the Earth's interior. The interpretation of  the images in terms of a physical state of the rocks requires calibration of seismic wave speeds as a function of factors such as temperature, size of the crystalline grains, presence of melt, and volatiles. Contrary to existing hypotheses, water has essentially no effect on seismic properties, decoupling its effects on rheology from seismic observations. Unexpectedly, the partial pressure of oxygen has a significant influence on seismic properties. More oxidized regions in the upper mantle (predominantly inferred to be the mantle wedge above subducting slabs) have slower wave speeds and higher attenuation compared to more reduced regions (most of the rest of the upper mantle). This finding may allow attribution of seismic velocity anomalies in the more reduced regions to other factors, for example the presence of melt.
